When you recognize incomplete letters, you are primarily using the Gestalt principle of...

open.q: Explain the difference between Bottom-Up and Top-Down processing in the context of perception.
open.solution: Bottom-Up processing starts at the sensory receptors and works its way 'up' to the brain. It is the data-driven analysis of sensory information. Top-Down processing is concept-driven; our brain uses our knowledge, expectations, and experiences to interpret and give meaning to sensory impressions.

uebungen.kreativ: Find a logo of a well-known brand. Which Gestalt principles are used in it to direct perception or convey a message?

6.title: Attention
6.grundwissen:
Attention is the selective concentration on certain aspects of the environment while ignoring others.Early theories tried to explain how this selection works:

  • Filter Theory (Broadbent, 1958): Attention as an early 'bottleneck'. Sensory information enters a store, a filter selects one channel based on physical characteristics (e.g., pitch, location). Only the information from this channel is processed further (semantic analysis). Unattended information is completely blocked.
  • Attenuation Theory (Treisman, 1964): Modification of Broadbent. The filter does not completely block unattended information but only weakens ('attenuates') it. Relevant or intense stimuli (like one's own name) can exceed the threshold and become conscious, even if they come from an unattended channel.
6.anwendbarkeit:
The Cocktail Party Effect

This phenomenon describes our ability to focus on a single conversation in a noisy environment (like a party) and tune out other sounds.

At the same time, we can perceive important stimuli from the ignored background noise, e.g., when someone calls our name.

  • Filter Theory *cannot* explain hearing one's own name, as it comes from an unattended channel and should be blocked.
  • Attenuation Theory can explain it: The other conversations are attenuated, but one's own name is a highly relevant stimulus that can penetrate even the attenuated channel.

This shows that selection is not always absolute and the meaning of stimuli plays a role.
6.meisterklasse:
Early vs. Late Selection & Resource Models

The debate continued: Does selection occur early (before meaning analysis) or late (after meaning analysis)?

  • Late Selection Theories (e.g., Deutsch & Deutsch): Argued that all stimuli are processed to the semantic level and selection occurs only afterward, based on relevance to the current task.

Modern View (Resource Models, e.g., Lavie): Attention is considered a limited resource. The depth of processing of irrelevant stimuli depends on how many resources the main task consumes:

  • High Perceptual Load (difficult task): Few resources left, irrelevant stimuli are filtered out early (supports early selection).
  • Low Perceptual Load (easy task): More resources available, irrelevant stimuli are more likely to be co-processed (supports late selection).

The locus of selection is therefore flexible and task-dependent.

quiz.q: Which theory postulates a complete block of unattended information?
The phenomenon of hearing your own name in a crowded room supports...

open.q: What is 'dichotic listening' and how was it used in attention research?
open.solution: In dichotic listening, a person is presented with different messages to each ear simultaneously via headphones. The person is instructed to pay attention to only one message (to 'shadow' it, i.e., repeat it aloud). Researchers then investigate what, if anything, is perceived from the unattended message. It was a key experimental paradigm for studying the selection mechanisms of attention.

uebungen.kreativ: Why is it so hard to follow a lecture when someone is whispering next to you, even if you try to ignore the whispering? Explain this using concepts of attention.

7.title: Sensory & Short-Term Memory
7.grundwissen:
Memory begins with very short-lived sensory stores before information enters short-term memory.

Sensory Memory

Holds an exact copy of sensory stimuli for a very short time:

  • Iconic Memory (visual): Stores visual information for approx. 250-500 milliseconds. Necessary, e.g., to connect letters into words when reading or to perceive movement as fluid.
  • Echoic Memory (auditory): Stores auditory information for approx. 2-4 seconds. Necessary to understand spoken language (to still have the beginning of a sentence 'present' when the end arrives).

Only information that is attended to is transferred to short-term memory.

Short-Term Memory (STM)

A store with limited capacity and duration that actively holds information we are currently processing.

  • Duration: Without active rehearsal, approx. 15-30 seconds.
  • Capacity: 'Magic Number' 7 Â± 2 units of information (Chunks) according to George Miller.
7.anwendbarkeit:
The 'Magic Number 7 +/- 2' & Chunking

George Miller (1956) noted that people can typically hold 5 to 9 (i.e., 7 Â± 2) unrelated units of information in short-term memory (e.g., digits, letters, words).

How then can we remember longer information like phone numbers? Through Chunking: We group individual elements into larger, meaningful units ('Chunks').

Example: The digit sequence 0 7 9 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 (10 digits) is hard to remember. Grouped as a phone number 079 123 45 67 (3 Chunks), it becomes easy.

Through chunking, we can increase the *amount* of information per chunk, thus expanding the effective capacity of short-term memory. Expertise in a field (e.g., chess) often relies on the ability to recognize complex patterns as chunks.
7.meisterklasse:
Baddeley's Working Memory Model

The concept of short-term memory was expanded by Baddeley & Hitch (1974) to Working Memory. It is not a passive store, but an active system for the short-term storage AND manipulation of information.

It consists of several components:

  • Central Executive: The 'conductor'. Controls attention, plans tasks, coordinates the subsystems.
  • Phonological Loop: Holds and manipulates linguistic information (like an inner voice and an inner ear). Important for remembering phone numbers, learning new words.
  • Visuospatial Sketchpad: Holds and manipulates visual and spatial information (mental images, orientation).
  • Episodic Buffer (added later): Integrates information from the loops and long-term memory into a coherent episode.

This model better explains why we can, for example, talk and navigate spatially at the same time (different subsystems), but have difficulty performing two linguistic tasks simultaneously (conflict in the phonological loop).

quiz.q: How long does information typically stay in short-term memory without rehearsal?
Which component of working memory is responsible for the 'mind's eye'?

open.q: What is the main difference between short-term memory according to Miller and working memory according to Baddeley?
open.solution: STM according to Miller is primarily a passive store with limited capacity (7Â±2 chunks). Working memory according to Baddeley is a more active, multi-component system that not only stores but also manipulates and processes information (e.g., mental arithmetic, spatial imagination), coordinated by the Central Executive.

uebungen.kreativ: Read a 7-digit phone number. Close your eyes and repeat it internally for 20 seconds. Which component of working memory did you primarily use?

8.title: Long-Term Memory
8.grundwissen:
Long-Term Memory (LTM) is our storage for information over long periods (minutes to a lifetime). It has a vast, potentially unlimited capacity.

Main subdivision:

  • Explicit (declarative) Memory: Consciously accessible memories that we can verbalize ('knowing that...').
    • Episodic Memory: Personal events and experiences (What did I have for breakfast yesterday? My first day of school).
    • Semantic Memory: Factual knowledge, word meanings, concepts (Paris is the capital of France. A dog has four legs).
  • Implicit (non-declarative) Memory: Unconscious memories that manifest in behavior ('knowing how...').
    • Procedural Memory: Learned skills and habits (riding a bike, typing, swimming).
    • Priming: The influence on the response to a stimulus by a previously presented stimulus.
    • Classical Conditioning: Learned emotional/physiological responses.
8.anwendbarkeit:
Mnemonic Techniques: Improving Learning Performance

Mnemonic techniques are memory aids that facilitate the encoding (storing) and retrieval of information, often through associations and organization.

  • Elaboration: Processing the learning material deeply, linking it to existing knowledge, finding examples, explaining in one's own words. (More effective than mere memorization).
  • Organization: Structuring information (e.g., mind maps, creating hierarchies).
  • Method of Loci: Mentally placing items to be remembered at locations along a familiar route and walking the route during retrieval.
  • Acronyms & Acrostics: Keywords (e.g., OCEAN for Big Five) or mnemonic sentences (e.g., 'My Very Educated Mother...' for planets).
  • Visual Imagery:Creating vivid mental images of the information to be remembered.

Study Tip: Don't just rely on repetition. Use elaboration and organization to anchor knowledge better in LTM.
8.meisterklasse:
Memory Consolidation & the Role of the Hippocampus

New explicit memories are initially fragile. The process by which they become stable and permanently anchored in long-term memory is called consolidation.

The Hippocampus (in the temporal lobe) plays a key role:

  • It acts as a 'director' or 'index' that links the different aspects of a new memory (visual, auditory, contextual), which are stored in different areas of the cortex, together.
  • During consolidation (which can take hours, days, or longer), these cortical connections are strengthened, and the memory becomes increasingly independent of the hippocampus.

The famous patient H.M., who had both hippocampi removed, could no longer form new explicit memories (anterograde amnesia), but his implicit memory remained intact. This demonstrated the specific role of the hippocampus in forming new explicit memories.

Sleep, especially deep sleep, is crucial for the consolidation of memory content.

quiz.q: The knowledge that Berlin is the capital of Germany belongs to...
Which structure is crucial for the formation of new explicit memories?

open.q: What is the difference between episodic and semantic memory?
open.solution: Both are parts of explicit memory. Episodic memory stores personal events with temporal and spatial context (e.g., 'What I had for lunch yesterday'). Semantic memory stores general factual knowledge about the world, detached from personal experience (e.g., 'A dog is a mammal').

uebungen.kreativ: Classify the following memories: a) Your memory of the last time you went to the movies, b) The ability to tie your shoelaces, c) Knowing that 3x4=12.

9.title: Implicit Memory & Memory Illusions
9.grundwissen:
Implicit memory influences our thinking and behavior without conscious recollection.

Forms of Implicit Memory

  • Procedural Memory: Learning skills (motor, cognitive). Becomes automated through practice (e.g., riding a bike, reading).
  • Priming: The processing of a stimulus is facilitated or influenced by the prior (often unconscious) presentation of a related stimulus. Example: After reading the word 'YELLOW', the word 'BANANA' is recognized faster.
  • Classical Conditioning: Learned associations between stimuli (e.g., Pavlov's dog).

Memory as Construction

Remembering is not a passive playback of a recording, but an active reconstruction process. We piece together stored fragments and often unconsciously fill gaps with our knowledge, expectations, and inferences. This makes memory efficient, but also prone to errors, distortions, and illusions.
9.anwendbarkeit:
Priming in Advertising

Advertising uses priming effects to evoke associations and influence purchasing decisions:

  • Brand Logos & Colors: Repeated presentation can prime positive feelings (through classical conditioning) or-specific concepts (e.g., 'luxury', 'safety').
  • Word Choice: Terms like 'natural', 'fresh', 'scientifically proven' can trigger corresponding associations and positive evaluations.
  • Context: Showing a product in a certain environment (e.g., happy family, successful athletes) primes associations between the product and that state.

These effects often work subtly and unconsciously.

Misinformation Effect

Memories can be altered by misleading information after the original event. Elizabeth Loftus demonstrated this in famous experiments: Witnesses to a car accident estimated the speed to be higher when asked how fast the cars 'smashed' into each other compared to 'hit' each other. The choice of words influenced the memory.
9.meisterklasse:
The DRM Paradigm: False Memories in the Lab

The Deese-Roediger-McDermott (DRM) paradigm shows how easily false memories of words that were never presented can arise.

Procedure: Lists of words are presented that are strongly associated with an unmentioned word (the 'critical lure') (e.g., bed, pillow, dream, night... lure: sleep).

Result: During later recall, many participants falsely, but often with high confidence, 'remember' hearing the critical lure ('sleep') as well.

Explanation: The presentation of the list words activates the semantic network and thus also the strongly associated lure. This high activation is misinterpreted during recall as actual perception.

Implications:Emphasizes the constructive nature of memory and the potential unreliability of recollections, e.g., in eyewitness testimony.

quiz.q: The improved ability to solve a task after being unconsciously exposed to relevant stimuli beforehand is called...
The misinformation effect (Loftus) shows that memories...
a: can be altered by subsequent information.
are always exact copies of reality.
are only stored in implicit memory.

open.q: Explain the difference between procedural memory and priming as forms of implicit memory.
open.solution: Procedural memory refers to the learning of skills and habits ('knowing how'), which become automated through practice (e.g., riding a bike). Priming refers to the unconscious influence on the processing of a stimulus by a previously presented stimulus, based on associations in memory.

uebungen.kreativ: Think about the last argument or disagreement you had. Is it possible that your memory of the conversation was unconsciously 'constructed' or distorted by your emotions or later thoughts about it? How?

10.title: Language
10.grundwissen:
Language is a system of symbols (words) and rules (grammar) used to communicate thoughts and feelings.

Levels of Language Structure

  • Phonology: The study of sounds (phonemes - smallest meaning-distinguishing sound unit, e.g., /b/ vs. /p/).
  • Morphology: The study of word components (morphemes - smallest meaning-carrying unit, e.g., 'run', '-s', 'un-').
  • Syntax: Rules of sentence formation (word order, sentence structure).
  • Semantics: The study of the meaning of words and sentences.
  • Pragmatics: Rules of language use in social context (e.g., politeness, understanding irony).
10.anwendbarkeit:
Sapir-Whorf Hypothesis: Does Language Influence Thought?

This hypothesis postulates a connection between the language we speak and the way we perceive and think about the world.

  • Strong Version (Linguistic Determinism): Language *determines* thought (largely disproven).
  • Weak Version (Linguistic Relativism): Language *influences* or *shapes* thought. The categories and structures of our language direct our attention and facilitate certain ways of thinking (finds more support).

Example: Languages that grammatically distinguish between animate and inanimate objects might encourage speakers to think differently about the 'animacy' of things. Or: Cultures with many words for snow perceive finer distinctions.

Language expands our thinking, but it does not completely restrict it.
10.meisterklasse:
Broca's and Wernicke's Aphasia

Damage to specific brain areas (usually the left hemisphere) leads to different language disorders (aphasias):

  • Broca's Aphasia (damage in the frontal lobe): Problems with language production. Speech is slow, halting, agrammatical ('telegraphic style'), but comprehension is relatively preserved. Sufferers often know what they want to say but cannot express it fluently.
  • Wernicke's Aphasia (damage in the temporal lobe): Problems with language comprehension. Speech is fluent but often content-empty, full of word substitutions or neologisms ('word salad'). Sufferers understand spoken and written language poorly and often do not notice their own errors.

These classic syndromes show the specialization of brain regions for different aspects of language processing, although modern research indicates a more complex network of areas involved.

quiz.q: The rules for correct sentence formation in a language are called...
Which language disorder is characterized by problems with language production but relatively good comprehension?

open.q: What is the difference between phonemes and morphemes?
open.solution: Phonemes are the smallest sound units that *distinguish* meaning (e.g., /k/ in 'cat' vs. /m/ in 'mat'). They do not carry meaning themselves. Morphemes are the smallest units that *carry* meaning (e.g., the word 'cat' or the plural ending '-s' in 'cats').

uebungen.kreativ: The sentence 'Time flies like an arrow; fruit flies like a banana.' plays with linguistic ambiguity (syntax and semantics). Explain why the second part of the sentence seems humorous or absurd.

11.title: Problem-Solving & Decision-Making
11.grundwissen:
Problem-solving is the process of overcoming obstacles to achieve a goal. Decision-making is the selection of one option from several alternatives.

Problem-Solving Strategies

  • Algorithm: A defined step-by-step procedure that guarantees a solution (e.g., mathematical formula, recipe). Effective, but often time-consuming or not available.
  • Heuristic: A mental shortcut or rule of thumb that often leads to a solution quickly but is error-prone. Efficient for complex problems.
    Examples:
    • Trial and Error.
    • Means-End Analysis: Reducing the difference between the current state and the goal state.
    • Working Backward: Starting from the goal state and working back to the beginning.

Obstacles to Problem-Solving

  • Mental Set: Sticking to a proven solution strategy even when it no longer fits.
  • Functional Fixedness: Seeing objects only in their usual function and overlooking alternative uses.
11.anwendbarkeit:
Judgment heuristics are mental shortcuts we use when assessing probabilities and making decisions. They are fast but often lead to systematic errors (biases).

Availability Heuristic

We estimate the frequency or probability of an event based on how easily examples come to mind (how 'available' they are in memory). Vivid, emotional, or recently experienced events are more available.

Example: After a spectacular plane crash in the news, many people overestimate the risk of flying compared to driving, although driving is statistically more dangerous.

Representativeness Heuristic

We estimate the probability that something belongs to a category based on how typical or 'representative' it seems for that category, often ignoring base rate information.

Example: Someone who is quiet, likes to read, and wears glasses â€“ are they more likely a librarian or a farmer? Many guess librarian because the description matches the stereotype, even though there are far more farmers than librarians (base rate).
11.meisterklasse:
Confirmation Bias

One of the most fundamental cognitive biases: The tendency to search for, interpret, and remember information that confirms our existing beliefs, and to ignore or devalue information that contradicts them.

Effects:

  • We persist in our opinions, even with counter-evidence.
  • Leads to polarization in groups ('filter bubbles').
  • Hinders scientific progress if researchers only look for confirming data.

Counter-strategy: Actively search for information that could refute one's own opinion ('falsification principle').

Framing Effect

The way a decision or information is presented ('framed') influences our judgment, even if the underlying facts are identical. Example: A yogurt is more likely to be bought if it is advertised as '90% fat-free' (positive frame) than '10% fat' (negative frame).

open.q: What is 'functional fixedness' and how does it hinder problem-solving?
open.solution: Functional fixedness is the cognitive block of seeing an object only in its typical or usual function. It hinders problem-solving because one overlooks creative, unconventional uses of the object that could lead to a solution (e.g., using pliers as a pendulum weight).

12.title: Artificial Intelligence & Cognition
12.grundwissen:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) attempts to simulate aspects of human cognition mechanically.

Basic Concepts

  • Machine Learning (ML): Algorithms that learn from data, recognize patterns, and make predictions without being explicitly programmed.
  • Neural Networks: ML models, inspired by the structure of the brain, consisting of interconnected 'neurons' (nodes) in layers. Learning occurs by adjusting connection strengths.
  • Deep Learning: Use of very deep (multi-layered) neural networks for complex tasks (image, speech recognition).
  • Natural Language Processing (NLP): AI methods for understanding and generating human language.

Modern AI, especially Deep Learning, has made impressive progress in areas formerly considered the domain of human cognition.
12.anwendbarkeit:
Ethical Implications of AI in Diagnostics & Therapy

The use of AI in healthcare and psychology holds great potential, but also significant ethical challenges:

  • Bias & Discrimination: If training data is unbalanced, AI can learn and amplify prejudices (e.g., in diagnosing certain groups).
  • Lack of Transparency ('Black Box'): It is often unclear how complex AI models arrive at their decisions, making verification and accountability difficult.
  • Accountability for Errors: Who is liable if an AI diagnosis is wrong or an AI therapy recommendation causes harm?
  • Data Privacy & Confidentiality: AI requires sensitive health data. How is its protection ensured?
  • Human Contact: Can and should AI replace the human therapist? Loss of empathy and the therapeutic relationship.
  • Patient/Client Autonomy: How is it ensured that AI recommendations do not undermine autonomy?

Responsible use requires careful review, regulation, and the maintenance of human oversight.
12.meisterklasse:
Cognitive Architectures vs. Modern AI Models

There are different approaches to artificially replicating cognition:

  • Cognitive Architectures (e.g., ACT-R, SOAR): Attempt to model the *structure* of human cognition through explicit modules (memory, perception, problem-solving) and symbolic rules. They are often more transparent and based on psychological theories. The goal is to understand human cognition.
  • Modern AI Models (e.g., Deep Learning): Often focus on performance on specific tasks. They learn patterns from large amounts of data, often without explicitly modeling the underlying cognitive processes. They are often more powerful but less interpretable ('Black Box').

Comparison Points:

  • Explainability: Architectures usually better, Deep Learning worse.
  • Learning: Architectures often rule-based, Deep Learning data-driven.
  • Biological Plausibility: Architectures often higher, Deep Learning loosely inspired.
  • Performance: Deep Learning often superior on specialized tasks.

The future may lie in hybrid approaches that combine the strengths of both directions (Neuro-symbolic AI).

open.q: What is the main difference between a cognitive architecture like ACT-R and a Deep Learning model?
open.solution: A cognitive architecture (ACT-R) tries to replicate the structure and function of human cognition through explicit, psychologically-founded modules and rules (symbolic approach). A Deep Learning model learns patterns and representations directly from large amounts of data using multi-layered neural networks, without necessarily explicitly modeling the human cognitive structure (connectionist/sub-symbolic approach).
